title: Night Work Health Surveillance
legalBasis: Workers' Statute (Royal Legislative Decree 2/2015) Article 36; Law 31/1995 on Occupational Risk Prevention; Royal Decree 39/1997 on Prevention Services; Royal Decree 1561/1995 on special working hours; Directive 93/104/EC on working time organization
summary:
Night workers — those who regularly work during the night period (22:00 to 06:00) — are entitled to specific protections including specialized health surveillance, limitations on working hours, and the right to transfer to day work if health problems arise due to night work. Article 36 of the Workers' Statute establishes that night work is that performed between 22:00 and 06:00, and defines a night worker as someone who performs at least three hours of their daily working time during this period, or someone who is likely to perform at least one-third of their annual working time during night hours. The hospitality sector relies heavily on night workers for bars, nightclubs, 24-hour restaurants, hotel night shifts, and security services.

Night work poses specific health risks that are well-documented in occupational health research. Disruption of circadian rhythms affects sleep quality and duration, leading to chronic sleep deprivation. Night workers experience higher rates of cardiovascular disease, gastrointestinal problems, metabolic disorders including diabetes, mood disorders including depression, and increased risk of certain cancers. The disruption to social and family life can create psychosocial stress. Accidents and errors are more common during night hours due to reduced alertness and cognitive performance. Recognizing these risks, Spanish and European law mandates that employers provide free health surveillance to night workers before starting night work and at regular intervals.

Health surveillance for night workers must assess fitness for night work considering factors including sleep quality, cardiovascular health, gastrointestinal symptoms, metabolic health, psychological well-being, and any medications or conditions that could be adversely affected by night work or that could impair safe performance during night hours. If health surveillance identifies problems related to night work, the employer must offer transfer to available day work positions. Employers must also ensure that night working hours do not exceed safe limits, provide adequate rest periods, and implement measures to mitigate the health impacts of night work including workplace lighting, rest facilities, and access to nutritious food.
keyPoints: Night work is defined as work between 22:00 and 06:00; night workers are those regularly working at least 3 hours daily or one-third of annual hours in this period
Free health surveillance is mandatory for night workers before starting night work and at regular intervals (typically annual)
Night workers' average working time must not exceed 8 hours in any 24-hour period measured over a 15-day reference period
Workers performing particularly hazardous night work must not exceed 8 hours in any single 24-hour period
If health problems certified as related to night work arise, employer must offer transfer to available day work with equivalent conditions
Night workers are entitled to refuse transfer to night work if it presents risk to health certified by medical services
Pregnant workers can request exemption from night work if medical certification indicates health risk
Workers over 50 years old may require more frequent health surveillance due to age-related vulnerability to circadian disruption
Health surveillance must assess cardiovascular health, sleep quality, gastrointestinal function, metabolic health, and psychological well-being
Employer must implement measures to mitigate night work health impacts including appropriate lighting, rest facilities, and nutritional support

sections.heading: 1. Legal Definition and Classification of Night Work
sections.content:
Article 36 of the Workers' Statute establishes clear definitions that determine which workers are subject to night work protections. Night time is defined as the period between 22:00 (10:00 PM) and 06:00 (6:00 AM), comprising eight hours of the 24-hour day. Night work is any work performed during this period, and a night worker is defined in one of two ways: either someone who performs at least three hours of their daily working time during the night period on a normal day, or someone who performs at least one-third of their annual working time during night hours. These alternative definitions capture both workers with permanently night-scheduled shifts and workers with rotating schedules who accumulate substantial night hours.

The definition is important because it determines entitlement to protections. A waiter who works until 23:00 (one hour into night period) is not classified as a night worker under the three-hour daily criterion, though if such shifts occur sufficiently frequently that they accumulate to one-third of annual hours, the annual criterion would apply. Conversely, a hotel night porter working 23:00 to 07:00 clearly works more than three hours nightly and is unambiguously a night worker. Employers must track working time to identify which workers meet night worker criteria and ensure they receive appropriate protections.

Collective agreements may define night work differently, potentially expanding the night period or providing additional protections, but cannot reduce protections below statutory minimums. For example, a collective agreement might define night work as starting at 20:00 or ending at 08:00, or might provide additional compensation for night work. Employers must comply with whichever definition — statutory or collective agreement — provides greater protection to workers. Some agreements distinguish between night work (any work during night hours) and night shift work (entire shifts scheduled during night hours), with different provisions for each.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Working Time Limitations for Night Workers
subsections.content:
Night workers' average working time must not exceed 8 hours in any 24-hour period, calculated over a reference period of 15 days. This means that while individual shifts might exceed 8 hours, the average over the 15-day period cannot. For example, a night worker might work 10-hour shifts for three nights followed by four nights off, with the average over the 15-day period remaining at or below 8 hours per 24-hour period. This limitation recognizes that long night shifts are particularly fatiguing and that recovery time between shifts is critical.

For workers performing particularly hazardous work during night hours — defined as work involving special risks identified in risk assessment, including certain chemical exposures, high-risk machinery operation, or work at height — the 8-hour limit applies to each individual 24-hour period, not as an average. These workers must not work more than 8 hours in any single night, with no possibility of averaging over longer periods. The strict limit reflects the elevated risk when fatigue from night work combines with inherently dangerous tasks. Employers must identify which night work roles involve particular hazards and apply the appropriate limits.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Rest Periods and Recovery Time
subsections.content:
While the Workers' Statute mandates minimum rest periods for all workers — 12 hours between working days and 1.5 days per week — night workers may require enhanced rest periods to compensate for the disruption to circadian rhythms. Best practice recommendations suggest that night workers should have at least 11 consecutive hours of rest between shifts (consistent with European Working Time Directive requirements), and that multiple consecutive night shifts should be limited (typically 3-4 consecutive nights maximum) with adequate recovery time before returning to night work.

Rotation patterns should be designed to minimize circadian disruption. Forward rotation (morning to evening to night) is generally better tolerated than backward rotation (night to evening to morning). Rapid rotation (changing shift pattern every 2-3 days) prevents full adaptation to night schedules but reduces chronic circadian disruption; slow rotation (weeks or months on night schedule) allows adaptation but creates long-term circadian misalignment. Permanent night shifts suit some workers who adapt their entire life schedule to nights, but exclude others with family or social constraints. Employers should consult with night workers about rotation preferences and provide flexibility where operationally possible.

sections.heading: 2. Mandatory Health Surveillance for Night Workers
sections.content:
Health surveillance for night workers is mandatory under Article 36.4 of the Workers' Statute and Articles 22 and 37 of Law 31/1995. The employer must provide, at no cost to the worker, health assessments before the worker begins night work and at regular intervals thereafter. The purpose is to identify health conditions that could be adversely affected by night work, to detect health problems arising from night work early enough for intervention, and to certify fitness for night work. The surveillance must be provided through the occupational health service (servicio de prevención), either an internal service within large organizations or more commonly an external specialized service contracted by the employer.

The initial health assessment before starting night work should include: detailed medical history including pre-existing cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, metabolic, or psychiatric conditions; assessment of current medications (some medications interact poorly with night work schedules); sleep history and assessment of sleep disorders; family history of conditions exacerbated by circadian disruption; physical examination including cardiovascular and abdominal examination; and baseline testing which may include blood pressure, heart rate, blood glucose, lipid profile, and other tests determined by the occupational physician based on individual risk factors and the nature of the night work.

Periodic health surveillance should be conducted at intervals determined by the occupational health service based on risk factors, but typically annually for night workers. More frequent surveillance may be indicated for workers over 50, workers with pre-existing health conditions, or workers performing particularly demanding or hazardous night work. The periodic assessment includes review of any health changes since the last assessment, specific inquiry about sleep problems, cardiovascular symptoms, gastrointestinal issues, weight changes, mood changes, or other concerns that could relate to night work, and appropriate examination and testing. The occupational physician provides the employer with a fitness certificate (fit for night work, fit with restrictions, or not fit) without disclosing specific medical details, which remain confidential.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Specific Health Risks of Night Work
subsections.content:
Cardiovascular disease risk is elevated in night workers, with research showing increased incidence of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and myocardial infarction. Mechanisms include circadian rhythm disruption affecting blood pressure regulation, reduced physical activity, poor dietary habits (night shift workers often rely on vending machines or fast food), and increased smoking rates among shift workers. Health surveillance should monitor blood pressure, assess cardiovascular symptoms (chest pain, palpitations, excessive fatigue), and evaluate risk factors including smoking, physical inactivity, and family history.

Gastrointestinal problems are common in night workers, ranging from minor dyspepsia and constipation to peptic ulcer disease. The digestive system operates on circadian rhythms; eating during hours when the body expects to be fasting disrupts normal gastric acid secretion and motility. Night workers often eat irregular meals, consume more caffeine to maintain alertness, and may use alcohol to aid sleep after night shifts. Health surveillance should inquire about abdominal pain, heartburn, bowel habit changes, and dietary patterns. Workers with significant gastrointestinal symptoms may benefit from dietary counseling and, if symptoms persist, may need to transfer to day work.

Metabolic disorders including obesity, type 2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome are more prevalent in long-term night workers. Circadian disruption affects glucose metabolism and appetite regulation hormones (leptin and ghrelin), promoting weight gain and insulin resistance. Health surveillance should include body mass index calculation, blood glucose testing (fasting glucose or HbA1c for workers with risk factors), and inquiry about symptoms of diabetes. Workers identified with pre-diabetes or metabolic syndrome should receive dietary and lifestyle counseling and closer monitoring.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Sleep Disorders and Fatigue Assessment
subsections.content:
Chronic sleep deprivation is almost universal among night workers. The challenge is that the body's circadian system promotes wakefulness during daylight hours, making daytime sleep after a night shift shorter, lighter, and more fragmented than nighttime sleep. Night workers typically obtain 1-2 hours less sleep per 24-hour period than day workers. Over time, this sleep debt accumulates, causing chronic fatigue, reduced cognitive performance, mood changes, and increased accident risk.

Health surveillance should include structured assessment of sleep quality and quantity using validated tools such as the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index or Epworth Sleepiness Scale. Inquiries should cover: average sleep duration, time taken to fall asleep, frequency of night awakenings, whether the worker wakes feeling refreshed, daytime sleepiness, use of sleep medications or aids, strategies used to manage sleep around shifts, and family or environmental factors affecting sleep (noisy household, young children, inadequate bedroom darkening). Workers reporting severe sleep problems, excessive daytime sleepiness, or probable sleep disorders (sleep apnea, insomnia) should be referred for specialist sleep medicine evaluation.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Psychological and Social Well-Being
subsections.content:
Night work disrupts social and family life, with workers being unavailable during conventional social hours, unable to attend family events or children's activities, and experiencing difficulties maintaining relationships. This social isolation contributes to higher rates of depression, anxiety, and relationship problems among night workers. The isolation is compounded when day-sleeping workers must reduce noise exposure and darken bedrooms, further separating them from household activities.

Health surveillance should include mental health screening using tools such as the PHQ-9 for depression or GAD-7 for anxiety. Open-ended questions about work-life balance, family relationships, social connections, and life satisfaction provide qualitative insight. Workers who report psychological distress, relationship problems attributable to night work, or social isolation should be offered counseling or occupational health psychology support. In some cases, transfer to day work may be necessary for mental health reasons. Employers should recognize that supporting night workers' well-being includes facilitating social connections among night shift workers (team building, shift gatherings) and, where possible, providing flexibility for important family events.

sections.heading: 3. Transfer to Day Work for Health Reasons
sections.content:
Article 36.4 of the Workers' Statute establishes that if health problems certified by occupational health services or public health services as connected to night work arise, the worker must be transferred to available day work compatible with their professional qualifications. This is a substantive right, not merely a recommendation. The employer cannot refuse transfer if a suitable day position exists, and cannot require the worker to accept inferior conditions. The transfer must be to a position with equivalent professional category and salary; night work supplement may be lost (as it relates specifically to night work), but base salary and overall remuneration package should be maintained as far as possible.

The certification that health problems are connected to night work must come from health professionals — either the occupational health service or the worker's treating physician in the public health system. The worker cannot simply request transfer because they prefer day work; medical evidence of health impact is required. However, the standard is not that night work has caused serious illness, but rather that health problems exist that are connected to night work or that night work is adversely affecting the worker's health. Conditions such as persistent insomnia, worsening hypertension, exacerbation of gastrointestinal disease, or developing depression can all justify transfer.

If no suitable day work position exists at the time the transfer is requested, the employer must offer transfer when a suitable position becomes available. During the interim, the employer should implement measures to mitigate health impacts: reducing night work hours if possible, providing enhanced support (counseling, dietary advice, sleep hygiene education), and maintaining regular review with occupational health to monitor the situation. If the employer fails to offer transfer when a suitable position exists, the worker can pursue labor claims for breach of statutory rights, potentially including compensation and orders compelling transfer.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Procedure for Requesting Transfer
subsections.content:
The worker seeking transfer to day work for health reasons should first raise concerns with the occupational health service during periodic health surveillance or by requesting an additional health assessment. The occupational physician will evaluate whether health problems are present and whether they are related to night work. If the physician determines that transfer is advisable, they will provide certification to this effect. The worker should then formally request transfer from the employer in writing, providing the medical certification.

The employer must respond within a reasonable timeframe, typically 30 days, either offering a specific day work position or explaining that no suitable position currently exists but the worker will be offered transfer when one becomes available. The offered position must be described in detail so the worker can assess whether it is genuinely equivalent. If the worker accepts, the transfer should be formalized with written confirmation of the new schedule, role, and conditions. The worker's employment contract is modified to reflect the transfer, but seniority and other accrued rights are maintained.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Protection Against Adverse Treatment
subsections.content:
Workers who request or receive transfer from night work to day work for health reasons are protected against dismissal or unfavorable treatment related to the transfer. The employer cannot use health-related transfer as a pretext for dismissal, demotion, or salary reduction beyond the loss of night shift supplement directly attributable to ceasing night work. Any dismissal occurring shortly after transfer request or completion would be scrutinized for connection to the transfer, with potential finding of unfair or discriminatory dismissal.

Workers should not fear career consequences from requesting transfer for health reasons. The law recognizes that not everyone can sustain night work long-term and that health protection takes priority over operational convenience. Employers benefit from accommodating transfer requests: retaining experienced workers, demonstrating duty of care that enhances reputation and morale, and avoiding the costs of dismissal-related litigation and hiring and training replacements. A culture that normalizes health-related transfers and supports workers through the process serves everyone's interests.

sections.heading: 4. Measures to Mitigate Night Work Health Impacts
sections.content:
While health surveillance identifies problems, employers should also implement proactive measures to minimize the adverse health effects of night work. Workplace lighting is critical: bright white or blue-spectrum light during night shifts helps maintain alertness by suppressing melatonin production, while dimmer warm lighting toward the end of the shift and avoiding bright light during the commute home facilitates the transition to sleep. Some employers provide light therapy visors or light boxes for night workers. Conversely, day-sleeping night workers should have access to blackout curtains or eye masks to darken sleeping environments, and ear plugs or white noise machines to reduce noise disturbance.

Nutrition and meal provisions for night workers require attention. Night shifts should include meal breaks with access to hot, nutritious food rather than forcing workers to rely on vending machines with high-sugar, high-fat snacks. Some employers provide subsidized meals for night workers or catered meal options. Education on nutrition for shift workers should emphasize: eating main meal before starting night shift, light snacks during shift rather than heavy meals, avoiding large meals close to sleep time, limiting caffeine to the first half of the shift, staying hydrated, and avoiding excessive alcohol as a sleep aid.

Rest facilities for night workers should provide comfortable seating, quiet space away from operational noise, facilities for heating food, and ideally short-duration nap facilities. Brief naps (15-20 minutes) during night shifts can significantly improve alertness, though longer naps (over 30 minutes) can cause sleep inertia and grogginess. Some industries (healthcare, emergency services, long-haul transport) have implemented managed nap policies showing benefits for safety and performance. Employers should explore whether such policies could be adapted to hospitality night work.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Training and Information for Night Workers
subsections.content:
Night workers should receive specific training on managing the health effects of shift work. Topics should include: circadian rhythm basics and why night work is challenging for the body; sleep hygiene strategies including sleeping environment optimization, pre-sleep routines, and managing sleep around shift schedules; nutrition strategies for night workers including meal timing and food choices that support alertness and health; signs of serious health problems that require medical attention including chest pain, severe headaches, significant mood changes; strategies for managing social and family life around night work; and resources available for support including occupational health, employee assistance programs, and external support groups.

Training should be provided before workers begin night schedules and refreshed periodically. Many night workers develop maladaptive coping strategies (excessive caffeine, using alcohol or sedatives to force sleep, inadequate rest periods) that worsen health impacts in the long term. Evidence-based guidance on effective strategies can help workers manage night work sustainably. Peer support groups where experienced night workers share successful strategies can be particularly valuable, as workers often trust advice from colleagues with lived experience over advice from health professionals who don't work nights themselves.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Monitoring and Evaluation of Night Work Health Programs
subsections.content:
Employers should monitor health outcomes among night workers to evaluate the effectiveness of health protection measures and identify areas requiring improvement. Metrics to track include: health surveillance findings aggregated at group level (prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors, gastrointestinal complaints, sleep problems); sickness absence rates among night workers compared to day workers; accident and incident rates during night shifts; turnover rates among night workers; and feedback from night workers about health support measures and workplace conditions.

Regular consultation with night workers provides qualitative insight into their experiences and suggestions for improvements. This can be accomplished through periodic surveys, focus groups, or representatives from night workers participating in health and safety committees. Workers often identify practical problems and solutions that management may not recognize — for example, lack of healthy food options at 3:00 AM, difficulty accessing occupational health services during waking hours when appointments are scheduled, or inadequate changeover time with day shift colleagues affecting information flow and increasing stress. Responding to worker feedback demonstrates genuine commitment to health protection and improves the effectiveness of measures implemented.

sections.heading: 5. Special Considerations for Vulnerable Workers
sections.content:
Certain groups of workers may be particularly vulnerable to the health effects of night work and require additional consideration. Pregnant workers are entitled to request exemption from night work if medical certification indicates that night work presents risks to pregnancy or fetus. The employer must accommodate this request by reassigning to day work or, if this is not possible, by granting suspension with pregnancy risk allowance. The request for night work exemption is separate from broader pregnancy risk accommodation and specifically addresses the circadian and fatigue-related risks of night work.

Workers over age 50 may experience increased difficulty with night work as aging affects circadian rhythm amplitude, sleep architecture, and recovery capacity. While there is no automatic exemption from night work based on age, occupational health services should consider age-related factors in health surveillance and may recommend more frequent surveillance or earlier intervention if health problems arise. Some collective agreements provide preferential access to day shifts for workers above a certain age (typically 55), recognizing the difficulty of sustaining night work into older working life.

Workers with chronic health conditions — particularly cardiovascular disease, diabetes, epilepsy, sleep disorders, or mental health conditions — may be at increased risk from night work. Pre-existing conditions may be exacerbated by circadian disruption, or the conditions may affect safe performance of night work (for example, diabetes control is more difficult with irregular meal times, epilepsy seizure risk may increase with sleep deprivation). Health surveillance for these workers should include coordination with treating physicians, individualized fitness assessment, and potentially more frequent surveillance to monitor condition stability.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Medication Management on Night Shifts
subsections.content:
Many medications are intended to be taken at specific times of day aligned with circadian rhythms. Night workers may struggle to adapt medication schedules to inverted sleep-wake patterns. For example, medications prescribed for morning dosing (to coincide with waking) should be taken when the night worker wakes in the afternoon, not at conventional morning hours. Medications for evening dosing should be taken before the night worker's sleep period (in the morning after night shift), not at conventional evening hours. However, many workers fail to adapt medication timing, reducing effectiveness and potentially causing side effects.

Occupational health services should review medication regimens for night workers during health surveillance and provide guidance on adapting dosing schedules. Some medications are particularly problematic for night workers: sedating medications that cause daytime drowsiness may be more problematic when 'daytime' is the working period; alerting medications or those causing insomnia may disturb day-sleep; medications requiring dosing with food may be complicated by irregular eating patterns. In some cases, consultation with the prescribing physician to adjust medication or timing may be necessary. Workers should be advised never to adjust prescribed medications without medical guidance.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Family and Social Support Considerations
subsections.content:
The impact of night work extends beyond the individual worker to affect their family. Partners of night workers often report disrupted sleep (trying to keep household quiet during day, disrupted by worker coming home), reduced quality time together (communication limited to brief overlaps between work schedules), and increased burden of household and childcare responsibilities. Children may be affected by reduced parent availability and unpredictable schedules. Extended family and friends may feel the worker is unavailable for social events that typically occur during evening hours when the night worker is sleeping or working.

Employers can support night workers' families through several measures: providing information to families about night work health impacts and how to support the night worker's sleep and well-being; scheduling policies that provide predictability (consistent shift patterns, advance notice of schedules) allowing families to plan around work; flexibility for important family events (allowing occasional shift swaps or time off for children's school events, partner's significant occasions); and recognizing the family impact in health surveillance discussions. Some employers extend employee assistance programs to workers' family members, providing counseling or support for relationship or family issues related to shift work. Supporting the night worker's family supports the worker's overall well-being and retention.

sections.heading: 6. Documentation and Compliance
sections.content:
Employers must maintain comprehensive documentation of night work health surveillance and related protective measures. For each night worker, records should include: identification of the worker as meeting night worker criteria (based on hours worked during night period); initial health surveillance report and fitness certificate before commencing night work; periodic health surveillance reports and fitness certificates; any medical certifications of health problems related to night work; correspondence regarding transfer to day work requests and outcomes; working time records demonstrating compliance with 8-hour average limit (or single-shift limit for hazardous work); and records of training provided on night work health management.

At organizational level, documentation should include: risk assessment specifically addressing night work hazards; policies and procedures for night work health surveillance, transfer to day work, and health protection measures; records of consultation with worker representatives on night work conditions; health surveillance provider contracts and credentials verification; and monitoring data on night worker health outcomes, sickness absence, and accidents. This documentation demonstrates compliance with legal obligations and provides evidence in the event of inspections, complaints, or litigation.

Regular review and audit of night work practices ensures ongoing compliance and identifies opportunities for improvement. Internal audits should verify: that all workers meeting night worker criteria have been identified and are receiving required health surveillance; that working time limits are being respected; that workers reporting health problems related to night work have been offered appropriate accommodation or transfer; that health surveillance is current for all night workers; and that protective measures (lighting, nutrition, rest facilities, training) are in place and effective. Findings from audits should be acted upon promptly, with corrective actions documented and completion verified.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Regulatory Inspections and Penalties
subsections.content:
Labor inspectors pay particular attention to night work compliance due to the documented health risks and the history of violations in sectors employing substantial night work. Inspections verify that night workers are receiving required health surveillance, that working time limits are respected, that workers requesting transfer for health reasons have been accommodated, and that overall protective measures are adequate. Common violations identified in inspections include: failing to provide health surveillance before workers begin night work; inadequate frequency of periodic health surveillance; working time records showing excessive night hours exceeding legal limits; failure to offer day work transfer when health problems certified; and inadequate risk assessment addressing night work-specific hazards.

Penalties for violations vary by severity. Failure to provide health surveillance or substantial working time limit violations are classified as serious infractions with fines typically ranging from €6,251 to €25,000 per worker affected. Repeated violations, violations affecting multiple workers, or violations resulting in serious health consequences for workers can be classified as very serious infractions with fines from €25,001 to €187,515. Beyond financial penalties, serious violations can result in orders to cease employing workers in night roles until compliance is achieved, effectively shutting down night operations until corrective actions are taken.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Best Practices for Night Work Management
subsections.content:
Organizations with well-managed night work programs share common features: senior leadership commitment to night worker health and safety, reflected in resource allocation and policy prioritization; comprehensive health surveillance with high-quality occupational health service providers and follow-through on recommendations; worker participation in developing night work policies and procedures, ensuring practical applicability and worker buy-in; flexibility in scheduling practices where operationally possible, accommodating individual differences in tolerance for night work; investment in environmental controls (lighting, facilities, food provision) that mitigate health impacts; regular review of health outcomes and continuous improvement based on data and worker feedback; and supportive culture where requesting health-related accommodations or transfer is normalized rather than stigmatized.

Organizations should benchmark against industry best practices and legal requirements in other jurisdictions. Some European countries have more stringent night work protections (for example, mandatory compensation time for night hours, stricter working time limits, or requirements for night work to be voluntary except where business necessity is clearly demonstrated). While Spanish law sets minimum standards, employers can voluntarily adopt enhanced protections that benefit worker health and can serve as competitive advantages in recruiting and retaining skilled workers in labor markets where night work is unpopular.

checklists.title: Initial Health Surveillance Before Night Work Checklist
items: Conduct detailed medical history including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, metabolic, and psychiatric conditions
Assess current medications and potential interactions with night work schedule
Evaluate sleep history and identify any pre-existing sleep disorders
Assess family history of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, or other conditions exacerbated by circadian disruption
Perform physical examination including cardiovascular and abdominal assessment
Measure blood pressure and heart rate
Conduct blood tests including glucose and lipid profile (based on risk assessment)
Assess body mass index and screen for obesity-related risks
Evaluate mental health status and screen for depression or anxiety
Provide fitness certificate specifying fit for night work, fit with restrictions, or not fit
Provide worker with education on health risks of night work and protective strategies
Document all findings and recommendations in confidential health record

checklists.title: Periodic Night Worker Health Surveillance Checklist
items: Review health changes since previous assessment
Assess sleep quality and duration using structured screening tools
Inquire about cardiovascular symptoms (chest pain, palpitations, fatigue)
Assess gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, heartburn, altered bowel habits)
Monitor weight changes and body mass index
Screen for metabolic changes (increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue suggesting diabetes)
Assess mental health including mood, anxiety, and work-life balance
Review medication adherence and timing on night shift schedule
Measure blood pressure and compare to baseline
Conduct laboratory testing as indicated by symptoms or risk factors
Update fitness certificate and advise on any necessary work accommodations
Recommend transfer to day work if health problems attributable to night work identified

checklists.title: Night Work Health Protection Implementation Checklist
items: Install bright white or blue-spectrum lighting in night work areas to support alertness
Provide access to nutritious meal options during night shifts, not just vending machines
Establish rest facilities with comfortable seating and quiet space
Provide education and resources on sleep hygiene and circadian rhythm management
Offer blackout curtains or eye masks to support day-sleeping
Limit consecutive night shifts to 3-4 nights with recovery period between sequences
Ensure night working hours do not exceed 8-hour average over 15-day periods
Establish clear procedure for workers to request day work transfer for health reasons
Provide access to occupational health service at times convenient for night workers
Consult night workers on scheduling practices and protective measures
Monitor health outcomes, sickness absence, and incidents among night workers
Review and update night work health protection measures annually

bestPractices: Offer voluntary night work where possible rather than mandatory assignment, allowing workers who tolerate night work well to self-select
Limit consecutive night shifts to 3-4 nights maximum, followed by at least 2-3 days off for circadian rhythm recovery
Provide bright lighting during night shifts (at least 1000 lux) to maintain alertness, with gradual dimming in the last hour to facilitate post-shift sleep transition
Ensure nutritious meal options are available during night shifts, ideally hot prepared food rather than only snacks and vending machines
Create opportunities for social connection among night workers (team meetings, social events at times convenient for night schedules) to reduce isolation
Implement forward-rotating schedules (day-evening-night) if using rotation, as this is better tolerated than backward rotation
Provide education specifically addressing night work health management, not generic health information
Monitor night worker health outcomes systematically and use data to evaluate effectiveness of protective measures and identify areas requiring enhancement

glossary.Night Work: Work performed between 22:00 and 06:00; creates specific health risks due to circadian rhythm disruption
glossary.Night Worker: Worker who regularly performs at least 3 hours daily work during night period, or at least one-third of annual working time during night hours
glossary.Circadian Rhythm: Approximately 24-hour biological cycle regulating sleep-wake patterns, hormone secretion, body temperature, and other physiological functions; disrupted by night work
glossary.Health Surveillance: Systematic monitoring of workers' health through medical examinations, testing, and assessments; mandatory for night workers before starting night work and at regular intervals
glossary.Transfer to Day Work: Legal right of night workers who develop health problems certified as related to night work to be reassigned to day work positions with equivalent conditions
glossary.Working Time Limit: For night workers, average working time must not exceed 8 hours per 24-hour period calculated over 15-day reference period; stricter limit for hazardous night work
glossary.Sleep Debt: Cumulative effect of chronic insufficient sleep; common in night workers due to shortened, disrupted day-sleep
glossary.Melatonin: Hormone that regulates sleep-wake cycles; secretion is suppressed by bright light and promoted by darkness; dysregulated in night workers
glossary.Forward Rotation: Shift rotation pattern progressing from day to evening to night shifts; generally better tolerated than backward rotation (night to evening to day)
